    Introduction Simple example Implementation Dynamics equations

Dynamics equations

2024-04-03

Source: vignettes/equations.Rmd
equations.Rmd

While salmonMSE reports state variables by year, the model is configured to model a population by successive generations. Thus, the dynamics equations are currently organized by life stage.

As model development continues, the dynamics can be stated by stock and year.

Definitions

Definition of variable names and the corresponding slots in either the input (SOM) or output (SMSE) objects in salmonMSE.

Name Definition Type Class Slot
\(\textrm{NOS}\) Natural origin spawners Natural production SMSE NOS
\(\textrm{HOS}\) Hatchery origin spawners Hatchery SMSE HOS
\(\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{eff}\) Effective number of HOS, spawning output discounted by \(\gamma\) Hatchery SMSE HOSeff
\(C_\textrm{smolt}\) Carrying capacity of smolts (stock-recruit parameter) Habitat SOM capacity_smolt
\(P_\textrm{smolt}\) Maximum rate of recruitment of smolts (stock-recruit parameter) Habitat SOM prod_smolt
\(u^\textrm{PT}\) Pre-terminal fishery harvest rate Harvest SOM u_preterminal
\(u^\textrm{T}\) Terminal fishery harvest rate Harvest SOM u_terminal
\(\textrm{Fec}\) Fecundity of spawners (eggs per female) Natural production SOM fec
\(\textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood}\) Fecundity of broodtake (eggs per female) Natural production SOM fec_brood
\(p^\textrm{female}\) Proportion of female spawners in broodtake and spawners Natural production + Hatchery SOM p_female
\(\textrm{SAR}\) Smolt-to-adult recruit survival Natural production + Hatchery SOM SAR
\(\textrm{NOB}\) Natural origin broodtake Hatchery SMSE NOB
\(\textrm{HOB}\) Hatchery origin broodtake Hatchery SMSE HOB
\(s_\textrm{yearling}\) Survival of hatchery eggs to yearling life stage Hatchery SOM s_egg_smolt
\(s_\textrm{subyearling}\) Survival of hatchery eggs to subyearling life stage Hatchery SOM s_egg_subyearling
\(p_\textrm{yearling}\) Proportion of hatchery releases as yearling (vs.Â subyearling) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(s_\textrm{prespawn}\) Survival of adult broodtake in hatchery Hatchery SOM s_prespawn
\(n_\textrm{yearling}\) Target number of hatchery releases as yearlings Hatchery SOM n_yearling
\(n_\textrm{subyearling}\) Target number of hatchery releases as subyearlings Hatchery SOM n_subyearling
\(p_\textrm{NOB}\) Proportion of the total broodtake of natural origin (vs.Â hatchery origin) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(p_\textrm{HOB}\) Proportion of the total broodtake of hatchery origin (vs.Â natural origin) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{max}\) Maximum proportion of the natural origin broodtake from the escapement, i.e., NOB/NOS ratio Hatchery SOM pmax_NOB
\(\textrm{NOR}\) Natural origin return Natural production SMSE Return_NOS
\(\textrm{HOR}\) Hachery origin return Hatchery SMSE Return_HOS
\(p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}\) Proportion of hatchery origin spawners removed from spawning grounds Hatchery SOM premove_HOS
\(\gamma\) Reduced reproductive success of HOS (relative to NOS) Hatchery SOM gamma
\(\Omega\) Selection strength relative to fitness variance Fitness SOM selection_strength
\(\theta\) Optimal phenotypic value for natural and hatchery population Fitness SOM theta
\(h^2\) Heritability of fitness traits Fitness SOM heritability
\(\sigma^2\) Phenotypic variation of fitness traits Fitness SOM fitness_variance
\(\textrm{PNI}\) Proportionate natural influence Fitness SMSE PNI
\(\ell_i\) Relative fitness loss at the i-th life stage (egg, fry, smolt) Fitness SOM rel_loss
\(\bar{p}\) Mean phenotypic value of natural and hatchery population Fitness Internal state variable -
\(f\) Population fitness Fitness SMSE fitness
\(m\) Mark rate of hatchery fish (affects fishery retention of hatchery fish relative to natural fish) Harvest SOM m
\(p_\textrm{NOS}\) Proportion of natural origin spawners (vs.Â effective HOS) Population dynamics Internal state variable -
\(p_\textrm{HOSeff}\) Proportion of effective hatchery origin spawners (vs.Â NOS) Population dynamics SMSE pHOS

Natural production

First, we consider natural production in the absence of fitness effects from the hatchery and habitat improvement.

Fry

From the spawners (NOS and HOS) of generation \(g-1\), the corresponding fry production for generation \(g\) is calculated as:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec}\\ \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \gamma \times \textrm{HOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \end{align}\]

Smolts

A Beverton-Holt stock-recruit relationship is used to calculate the smolt production

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}}{C_\textrm{smolt}}}\\ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}}{C_\textrm{smolt}}} \end{align}\]

Hatchery production

Broodtake

The target broodtake is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Broodtake} = \dfrac{n^\textrm{yearling}}{s^\textrm{prespawn} p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood} s^\textrm{yearling}} + \dfrac{n^\textrm{subyearling}}{s^\textrm{prespawn} p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood} s^\textrm{subyearling}} \]

The natural broodtake is

\[ \textrm{NOB}_{g-1} = \textrm{max}(p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{target} \times \textrm{Broodtake}, p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{max} \times \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_{g-1}) \]

The hatchery broodtake is

\[ \textrm{HOB}_{g-1} = \textrm{min}(\textrm{Broodtake} - \textrm{NOB}_{g-1}, \textrm{HOR}^\textrm{escapement}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}) \]

Smolt releases

From the total broodtake \(\textrm{NOB}_{g-1}\) and \(\textrm{HOB}_{g-1}\), the smolt releases is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g = (\textrm{NOB}_{g-1} + \gamma \times \textrm{HOB}_{g-1}) s^\textrm{prespawn}p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood}s^\textrm{hatchery} \]

where the average survival of all hatchery from the egg to yearling stage is

\(s^\textrm{hatchery} = s^\textrm{subyearling} (1 - p^\textrm{yearling}) + s^\textrm{yearling} p^\textrm{yearling}\) and \(p^\textrm{yearling} = n^\textrm{yearling}/(n^\textrm{subyearling} + n^\textrm{yearling})\).

Pre-terminal fishery

Harvest \(u^\textrm{PT}\)in the pre-terminal fishery occurs simultaneously along with marine survival (\(\textrm{SAR}\), constant base term). Pre-terminal fishery catch of immature NOS of generation \(g\) is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{NOS,PT}_g = \dfrac{F^\textrm{PT}_g}{Z^\textrm{PT}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT}_g))[\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g + \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g] \]

where \(F^\textrm{PT}_g\) is solved such that \(u^\textrm{PT} = \frac{F^\textrm{PT}_g}{Z^\textrm{PT}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT}_g))\), \(Z^\textrm{PT}_g = F^\textrm{PT}_g + M^\textrm{SAR}_g\).

In the absence of fitness effects, \(M^\textrm{SAR}_g = -\log(\textrm{SAR})\).

Similarly, the pre-terminal fishery catch of immature HOS in generation \(g\) is

\[ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{HOS,PT}_g = \dfrac{F_g^\textrm{PT}}{Z^\textrm{PT}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT}_g))\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g \]

Recruitment

The recruitment is calculated as the survival of smolts after pre-terminal harvest and marine survival:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOR}_g &= \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT})[\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g + \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g]\\ \textrm{HOR}_g &= \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT})\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g \end{align}\]

Terminal fishery

Catch of the terminal fishery is calculated from the harvest rate \(u^T\):

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{NOS,T}_g &= u^\textrm{T} \textrm{NOR}_g\\ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{HOS,T}_g &= u^\textrm{T} \textrm{HOR}_g \end{align}\]

Escapement

The escapement consists of the survivors of the terminal fishery:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g &= (1 - u^\textrm{T}) \textrm{NOR}_g\\ \textrm{HOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g &= (1 - u^\textrm{T}) \textrm{HOR}_g \end{align}\]

Spawners

The abundance of natural origin spawners consists of the escapement reduced by the broodtake. A separate removal term is used for hatchery origin spawners are removed, where the fish removed can be used as broodtake, research purposes, management of population fitness, etc.

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g - \textrm{NOB}_g\\ \textrm{HOS}_g &= \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g (1 - p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}) \end{align}\]

Habitat improvement

Habitat improvement can improve either the productivity parameter, capacity parameter, or both.

Base terms \(P_\textrm{smolt}\) and \(C_\textrm{smolt}\) are used in the historical period of the model, e.g., for conditioning from data. In the projection, the stock recruit parameters \(P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime\) and \(C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime\) are updated with the improvement parameters, \(I_P\) or \(I_C\), as specified in the operating model:

\[\begin{align} P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime &= P_\textrm{smolt}I_P\\ C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime &= C_\textrm{smolt}I_C \end{align}\]

Fitness effects on productivity

Reproductive success of hatchery fish has been observed to be lower than their natural counterparts, either through genetic or epigenetic causes.

The population fitness for generation \(g\) is

\[ f_g = \exp\left(-0.5\dfrac{(\bar{p}_g^\textrm{natural} - \theta^\textrm{natural})^2}{\omega^2 + \sigma^2}\right) \] where

\[\begin{align} \bar{p}_g^\textrm{natural} &= B + D\\ \bar{p}_g^\textrm{hatchery} &= b + d \end{align}\]

\[\begin{align} A &= \dfrac{\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural}\omega^2 + \theta^\textrm{natural}\sigma^2}{\omega^2+\sigma^2}\\ B &= p^\textrm{NOS}[\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural} + (A - \bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural})h^2]\\ C &= \dfrac{\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery}\omega^2 + \theta^\textrm{natural}\sigma^2}{\omega^2+\sigma^2}\\ D &= p^\textrm{HOSeff}[\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery} + (C - \bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery})h^2]\\ \end{align}\]

\[\begin{align} a &= \dfrac{\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery}\omega^2 + \theta^\textrm{hatchery}\sigma^2}{\omega^2+\sigma^2}\\ b &= p^\textrm{HOB}[\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery} + (a - \bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{hatchery})h^2]\\ c &= \dfrac{\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural}\omega^2 + \theta^\textrm{hatchery}\sigma^2}{\omega^2+\sigma^2}\\ d &= p^\textrm{NOB}[\bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural} + (c - \bar{p}_{g-1}^\textrm{natural})h^2]\\ \end{align}\]

\[ \omega = \Omega \sigma \]

Fitness reduces survival in the egg, fry, and smolt life stages:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \times f_g^{\ell_\textrm{egg}}\\ \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \gamma \times \textrm{HOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \times f_g^{\ell_\textrm{egg}} \end{align}\]

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime f_g^{\ell_\textrm{fry}} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}{C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}}\\ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime f_g^{\ell_\textrm{fry}} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}{C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}} \end{align}\]

\[ M^\textrm{SAR}_g = -\log(\textrm{SAR} \times f_g^{\ell_\textrm{smolt}}) \]
